discussion.content: Certainly an odd question - Serial console is not going to be anyone's go-to solution for making changes to the local firewall on an Azure VM. It is, however, the only option in the list where this task could be accomplished. I agree with the answer provided.

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT
-

You have an Azure virtual machine named VM1 that runs Windows Server.

You need to perform the following tasks on VM1:

• Configure Windows Defender Firewall to allow Remote Desktop connections,
• Configure where to store the logs of the virtual machine console.

Which two settings should you use? To answer, select the settings in the answer area.

NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point,

//IMG//

You have an Azure virtual machine named VM1. Crash dumps for a process named Process1 are enabled for VM1.
When process1.exe on VM1 crashes, a technician must access the memory dump files on the virtual machine. The technician must be prevented from accessing the virtual machine.
To what should you provide the technician access?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
May be C. an Azure Blob Storage container

comments.content: Stop posting Chat GPT and AI content, we do not need you to gather such content.
This comment needs to be removed. Do not use ChatGPT as a justification here - it is very very frequently incorrect.
ChatGPT = Not a substitute for actual research.

discussion.content:
chatgpt: 
To provide the technician access to the memory dump files from the crashed process without allowing access to the virtual machine itself, you should store the memory dump files in an external location, such as Azure Blob Storage container. This way, the technician can access the dump files without accessing the VM.

So, the correct choice is:

C. an Azure Blob Storage container

Selected Answer: B
Log analytics workspace, a raw storaged just contain data to be analyzed with some tool:
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/azure-monitor/agents/diagnostics-extension-logs#supported-data-types

Selected Answer: C
From the link given

Crash dumps (logs) Information about the state of the process if an application crashes.

No mention of file share, log analytics workspace and managed disk so C is correct

Azure Diagnostics extension (Agent) is used.
Use Azure Diagnostics extension if you need to send data to Azure Storage for archiving or to analyze it with tools such as Azure Storage Explorer.

Selected Answer: B
Without additional infrastructure (a configured collector) or clarification that "event subscription" means something unconventional, this solution doesn’t fully ensure that Microsoft Sentinel can collect Windows Firewall logs from Server1. The most straightforward and complete method—installing the Log Analytics Agent on Server1—is not part of the proposed solution.

questions.question_text:
Note: This question is part of a series of questions that present the same scenario. Each question in the series contains a unique solution that might meet the stated goals. Some question sets might have more than one correct solution, while others might not have a correct solution.

After you answer a question in this section, you will NOT be able to return to it. As a result, these questions will not appear in the review screen.

You have an on-premises server named Server1 that runs Windows Server.

You have a Microsoft Sentinel instance.

You add the Windows Firewall data connector in Microsoft Sentinel.

You need to ensure that Microsoft Sentinel can collect Windows Firewall logs from Server1.

Solution: You enable event subscription on Server1.

Does this meet the goal?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: CD
A is not needed, as Azure Arc is not needed for log collection. D is correct since we are connecting the VM to the Log Analytics workspace.

Selected Answer: AC
Azure Connected Machine agent: This agent is installed on each on-premises VM to onboard it to Azure Arc. For non-Azure machines, such as on-premises VMs, the Azure Monitor agent requires Azure Arc connectivity to function, making this a necessary first step.
Azure Monitor agent: Once the VMs are connected via Azure Arc, this agent is deployed as an extension to collect events. It supports advanced filtering through DCRs, meeting the requirement to minimize event volume, and sends the filtered data to Workspace1.

Selected Answer: AC
As they are on premise resource and we have no other information it's A&C. Source: have >10k endpoints in Azure Arc :)

Selected Answer: CD
I think it should be C & D. 
please let me know if I am wrong
for me i C and D

choices.B: the Azure VM Dependency agent extension for Windows
choices.D: the Log Analytics VM extension for Windows

questions.question_text:
You have 20 on-premises virtual machines that run Windows Server.

You have an Azure subscription that contains a Microsoft Sentinel workspace named Workspace1.

You need to collect events from the on-premises virtual machines end forward the events to Workspace1. The solution must ensure that you can define filters to minimize the volume of collected events.

Which two components should you install on each virtual machine? Each correct answer presents part of the solution.

NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
B. Connection monitor

Selected Answer: B
Answer is B

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/network-watcher/connection-monitor-overview

You need to identify the latency between the on-premises network and VM1.
